conclusion: The steel balls are released one after another at 0.10 s intervals from the same point, so each ball has been accelerating down the incline for a different amount of time when the snapshot is taken.
Because every ball starts from rest and slides (or rolls) down the same incline, their motions can be treated as uniform acceleration motions with the same acceleration a along the slope.
Let the time that the top ball (call it A) has been moving be t s.
Then ball B was released 0.10 s earlier, so its travel time is t + 0.10 s; ball C has been in motion t + 0.20 s, and so on.
With identical acceleration a, the distance s that a ball travels from its release point after time T is s = ½ a T².
Hence the distances measured along the slope are related by AB = ½ a [(t + 0.10)² – t²] and BC = ½ a [(t + 0.20)² – (t + 0.10)²].
Substitute the measured lengths (AB = 0.15 m, BC = 0.20 m) and solve the two equations for a and t.
Doing so gives a ≈ 4.7 m/s² and t ≈ 0.17 s.
Therefore the acceleration of any of the balls along the incline is about 4.7 m/s², and the top-most ball (A) in the picture has been rolling for roughly 0.17 s when the photograph was taken.
